meta.title: Osteopathic manipulative treatment: Tender points and counterstrain

content:
Introduction

Tender points are discrete, highly sensitive areas associated with somatic dysfunctions and located in muscles, fascia, tendons, and ligaments.  Counterstrain, an osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) technique, utilizes these tender points diagnostically and therapeutically.  This article outlines the pathophysiologic basis, precise anatomic locations, and diagnostic implications of tender points, and the therapeutic approach of counterstrain.

Pathophysiology



Tender points are tender nodules, generally 1-2 cm in diameter, that occur due to inappropriate neuromuscular reflexes following injury, strain, or chronic dysfunction.  Tender points represent altered proprioceptive reflexes, causing sustained muscle contraction and localized ischemia, thereby leading to pain and tenderness.  Counterstrain seeks to interrupt these reflexive cycles by positioning the patient to relax the affected tissues, diminishing neuromuscular strain and pain.  This is typically performed by positioning the patient to shorten the involved muscle.  An exception is for so-called "maverick tender points," which are uncommon and follow different rules for counterstrain: for these points (typically found in the cervical spine), counterstrain is performed by positioning the patient to lengthen the involved muscle.



The following section outlines how to perform the counterstrain technique.  Specific tender points, which are systematically categorized by anatomic region, are discussed later in the article.  Tender points differ from trigger points in that tender points do not typically radiate pain when palpated, though they are notably sensitive and painful.

Counterstrain technique



Counterstrain is a gentle, indirect, and passive treatment modality that positions the patient's body in a manner that reduces tenderness and allows neuromuscular reflexes to normalize.  The following provides a generalized approach to performing counterstrain:

Identify the tender point



The physician palpates anatomic areas for suspected tender points.  A positive point is one that produces a focal, sharp pain response with gentle pressure, usually rated at least 7 out of 10 in tenderness.

Establish a baseline



Once a tender point is located, the physician asks the patient to quantify the tenderness level.  This allows for comparison after treatment.

Position for comfort



The patient is then passively positioned such that the tenderness at the point is reduced by at least 70%.  This usually involves shortening the muscle associated with the tender point (except for maverick tender points).  Positioning can include flexion, extension, rotation, sidebending, or limb adjustments.

Fine-tune the position



Small adjustments in positioning are made to find the most comfortable position.

Hold the position



The final position is held for 90 seconds.  During this time, the muscle spindle activity normalizes, and the proprioceptive reflex resets.  It is critical that the patient remains passive and relaxed.

Slowly return to neutral



After the 90-second hold, the patient is slowly and passively returned to a neutral position to avoid reactivating the dysfunction.

Reassess



The clinician palpates the original tender point to assess reduction of pain and tension.  A successful treatment will result in a significant reduction or resolution of the tenderness.



For example, counterstrain for the psoas major muscle involves monitoring the tender point (located two-thirds of the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine [ASIS] and midline) while flexing the hip until pain is minimized (

image 1
).  This sequence is repeated for each tender point identified in a treatment session.  The following section discusses specific tender points and treatment positions.

Cervical tender points



Anterior and posterior cervical tender points are discussed below and summarized in the following table (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  Counterstrain treatment positions, which involve moving the neck, are described.

Anterior cervical (AC)



  • AC1:
    • Location:  Near the angle of the mandible and transverse process (TP) of C1.
    • Position:  Marked rotation away to lengthen (maverick point).
  • AC2-AC6:
    • Location:  Anterolateral aspect of corresponding TP.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend away, rotate away (F, SA, RA).
  • AC7:
    • Location:  On clavicle, near clavicular attachment of sternocleidomastoid (SCM).
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend toward, rotate away (F, ST, RA) (maverick point).
  • AC8:
    • Location:  On clavicle, near sternal SCM attachment.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend away, rotate away (F, SA, RA).

Posterior cervical (PC)



  • PC1 (midline):
    • Location:  Just lateral to the inion.
    • Position:  Flex (maverick point) with fine-tuning with sidebending and rotation.
  • PC1 (lateral):
    • Location:  Between inion and mastoid process.
    • Position:  Extend, sidebend away, rotate away (E, SA, RA).
  • PC2 (midline):
    • Location:  Superior aspect of C2 spinous process (SP).
    • Position:  Extend, sidebend away, rotate away (E, SA, RA).
  • PC2 (lateral):
    • Location:  On inferior nuchal line.
    • Position:  Extend, sidebend away, rotate away (E, SA, RA).
  • PC3 (midline):
    • Location:  Inferior aspect of C2 SP.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend away, rotate away (F, SA, RA).
  • PC3-PC7 (lateral):
    • Location:  Posterolatreal aspect of corresponding articular process.
    • Position:  Extend, sidebend away, rotate away (E, SA, RA).
  • PC4-PC8 (midline):
    • Location:  Inferior aspect of the SP of the above vertebrae (C3-C7).
    • Position:  Extend, sidebend away, rotate away (E, SA, RA).

Thoracic tender points



Anterior and posterior thoracic tender points are discussed below and summarized in the following table (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Counterstrain treatment positions, which involve moving the torso, are described.

Anterior thoracic (AT)



  • AT1:
    • Location:  Midline at the sternal notch.
    • Position:  Flex.
  • AT2-AT6:
    • Location:  Midline at the sternocostal junctions.
    • Position:  Flex.
  • AT7-AT11:
    • Location:  Midline and lateral to the rectus abdominis (bilaterally).
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend toward, rotate away (F, ST, RA).
  • AT12:
    • Location:  Superior to the ASIS, near iliac crest.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend toward, rotate away (F, ST, RA).

Posterior thoracic (PT)



  • PT1-PT12:
    • Location:  Tender points can vary and may be found on the spinous or transverse processes.
    • Position:  Extend the torso and sidebend away (E, SA).  For tender points on the SP, rotate away (E, SA, RA).  For tender points on the TP, rotate toward (E, SA, RT).

Rib tender points



Anterior and posterior rib tender points are discussed below and summarized in the following table (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  Counterstrain treatment positions, which involve moving the torso, are described.

Anterior ribs (AR)



  • AR1:
    • Location:  Sternocostal junction of rib 1.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend toward, rotate toward (F, ST, RT).
  • AR2:
    • Location:  Over rib 2 along midclavicular line.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend toward, rotate toward (F, ST, RT).
  • AR3-AR10:
    • Location:  Over corresponding rib (3-10) along anterior axillary line.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend toward, rotate toward (F, ST, RT).

Posterior ribs (PR)



  • PR1:
    • Location:  1" lateral to the articulation of rib 1 and the T1 TP.
    • Position:  Extend, sidebend away, rotate toward (E, SA, RT).
  • PR2-PR10:
    • Location:  Angle of the corresponding rib (2-10).
    • Position:  Sidebend away, rotate away.  Fine-tuning with slight flexion or extension may be needed.

Lumbar tender points



Anterior and posterior lumbar tender points are discussed below and summarized in the following table (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
).  Counterstrain treatment positions, which involve moving the leg and hip, are described.

Anterior lumbar (AL)



  • AL1:
    • Location:  Near the ASIS.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend toward, rotate away (F, ST, RA).
  • AL2-AL4:
    • Location:  Around the anterior inferior iliac spine.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend away, rotate toward (F, SA, RT).  Slight variations exist.
  • AL5:
    • Location:  On the pubic symphysis.
    • Position:  Flex, sidebend away, rotate away (F, SA, RA).

Posterior lumbar (PL)



  • PL1-PL5
    • Location:  On the corresponding SP and TPs.
    • Position:  Extend, sidebend away, rotate away (E, SA, RA).

Pelvic tender points



Anterior and posterior pelvic tender points are discussed below and summarized in the following table (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).

Anterior pelvic



  • Psoas major:
    • Location:  Two-thirds of the distance between the ASIS and midline.
    • Position:  Hip flexion.
  • Psoas minor (ie, low ileum):
    • Location:  Just lateral to the pubic symphysis.
    • Position:  Hip flexion.
  • Iliacus:
    • Location:  One-third of the distance between the ASIS and midline.
    • Position:  Flex the hip and knees, cross legs in a frog-leg position (
      image 2
      ).
  • Pectineus (inguinal):
    • Location:  On the superior pubis.
    • Position:  Flex the hip and knee, cross opposite leg over the affected leg, and internally rotate.

Posterior pelvic



  • Piriformis:
    • Location:  7 cm medial to and slightly above the greater trochanter.
    • Position:  With the patient prone, the hip and knee are flexed and abducted.  Then fine-tuning with internal rotation or external rotation is added.
  • Upper pole L5 (UPL5):
    • Location:  Just above the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS).
    • Position:  With the patient prone, extend the hip, adduct and fine-tune with rotation of the thigh internally/externally.
  • Lower pole L5 (LPL5):
    • Location:  Just above the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS).
    • Position:  With the patient prone, flex and adduct the hip.  Then internally rotate the thigh.

Extremity tender points

Upper extremities



  • Levator scapula:
    • Location:  Superior angle of the scapula.
    • Position:  Extend the shoulder and retract the scapula.
  • Supraspinatus:
    • Location:  Within the supraspinatus muscle or greater tuberosity of the humerus.
    • Position:  Abduct the arm to 45 degrees.
  • Subscapularis:
    • Location:  Anterolateral scapula (near axillary region).
    • Position:  Extend, internally rotate, and slightly abduct the arm.
  • Acromioclavicular:
    • Location:  On the AC joint.
    • Position:  Flex and adduct the shoulder while applying slight traction downward.
  • Radial head:
    • Location:  Anterolateral or posterolateral head of radius.
    • Position:  Extend the elbow and supinate.  Fine-tune with ulnar abduction/adduction.
  • Wrist:
    • Location:  Distal forearm.
    • Position:  Flex the wrist (for flexor tender point) or extend the wrist (for extensor tender point).

Lower extremities



  • Lateral trochanter:
    • Location:  On lateral thigh between greater trochanter and knee.
    • Position:  Abduct and slightly externally rotate the knee.
  • Patella:
    • Location:  On the patellar tendon.
    • Position:  Translate the distal femur posteriorly while supporting the ankle.
  • Menisci:
    • Location:  On the medial or lateral meniscus.
    • Position:  Flex the knee.  Then fine-tune with internal rotation and adduction (medial meniscus) or external rotation and abduction (lateral meniscus).
  • Anterior cruciate ligament:
    • Location:  On the distal hamstring.
    • Position:  Translate the proximal tibia posteriorly.
  • Posterior cruciate ligament:
    • Location:  Near the posterior tibial plateau (popliteus muscle).
    • Position:  Translate the distal femur posteriorly.
  • Ankles:
    • Location:  Anterior and inferior to the lateral malleolus (lateral ankle) or inferior to the medial malleolus (medial ankle).
    • Position:  Evert the foot (lateral) or invert the foot (medial).

Summary



Tender points represent focal neuromuscular dysfunctions that are sensitive to palpation and indicative of underlying somatic dysfunctions.  They are treated with counterstrain, an osteopathic manipulative therapy technique based on passive positioning and neuromuscular reflex reset.  Understanding the anatomic distribution and diagnostic significance of tender points, as well as the therapeutic application of counterstrain, is important.  This article provided a comprehensive list of tender points with tables.  A summary of treatment position rules is shown in the following table (
